bibl.title: Letter from Lee Rice to Henry Rose Carter, June 8, 1923

div1.p: Rice describes hemorrhaging in pregnant women and children associated with dengue fever.

div1.head: Letter from Lee Rice to Henry Rose Carter, June 8, 1923
div1.opener:
Miss
Book
Dengue
LEE RICE M.D.
AMERICAN NATIONAL BLDG.
GALVESTON, TEXAS
8 June 1923.
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
The uterine oozing which occurs in pregnant women with
Dengue Fever, begins with the onset of the illness, but the gastric hemorrages
that we saw occured at the heighth of the fever on the third, fourth, or fifth
day, and one young woman vomited digested blood in considerable amounts on
the seventh day. The intestinal hemorrages were noted at the same period also.

We frequently saw nose bleed in children during the first
days, and an occasional gastric hemorrage which we considered of no consequence.
In fact we laid no stress on hemorrages at any stage of the disease because
the liver is probably not damaged to any extent by Dengue, but they were in-
teresting in relation to the published descriptions, and I was reporting facts.

I have a rather fixed impression that the color of a yellow-
fever patient is a little darker, and more important, it is a little deeper below
the surface. One thinks it may be subcuticular, but if you say the facies are
identical, I shall not doubt it.

The second paper on this epidemic represents more work, and
I hope you will give me your opinion concerning it.
With my best wishes, I am
